"# TELOS

## PROBLEMS
p1: I do not want organizations and business to be hacked and lose their value. 
p2: I want to be able to not depend on my job to provide income for my family. 
p3: People lack any sort of religious depth, and are just here to make money and leave. 
p4: People are not experts in their craft, nor do they want to be. We are left learning surface level things from 5 second videos.
p5: We focus so much on defensive security, but we have no intelligence or offense toward countries that threaten us. 
p6: Telecommunications are how bad people communicate and plan bad things. We cannot understand this intelligence because we do not have security professionals skilled enough to hack these networks and gain intelligence on terrorist attacks, bombings, etc. 
p7: America is wildly distracted, over eating, watching shows. It is causing us to be behind. 
p8: Dad's do not spend enough time in their spiritual life or any effort to be a good father and husband. 
p9: People do not know how to protect themselves from physical threats. 
p10: People are not adapting to transformative technologies like AI.
p11: People do not study or have a mission to become an expert in a craft or skill, therefore they have no passion in what they are doing in life. 
## MISSION
m1: I think one of the biggest problems in the world is lack of privacy, therefore I want to develop skills in how to keep our personal lives private. 
m2: I think one of the biggest problems in the world is bad security architecture, therefore I want to be able to understand what good security looks like and educate people on this by being an autodidact
m3: I think one of the biggest problems in the world is depending on one income and job, I want to be able to build a business that can supplement my income and provide for my family. 
m4: I think one of the biggest problems is that Jesus Christ is real, and people do not believe that. I am here to make sure he name is known and my family follows the way of the Christian life. 
m5: One of the biggest problems I think is that people only dive surface level into their craft. I am here to become an expert, become a grand master so to speak, and utilize AI to my advantage. Not as a crutch. 
m6: I am here to make the world a safer place through the use of my Cyber skillsets, and I intend to understand how to hack, how to secure, and how to program in a way that allows me to do these things, and not just depend on AI at a surface level. 
m7: Most people over spend and do not allocate enough money for investments. I am going to save as much as I can in investments, house savings, HSA, Darling and Divine in order to have a FAST retirement (not actual retire), but have enough to not depend on my job at the EARLIEST age possible. I will ensure that most of my assets are above 50% stocks.
m8: I am on a mission to become the best dad and husband I can be for my wife, and raise my kids to have a happy, passionate, life. 
m9: I am on a mission to find security vulnerabilities, write reports on them, and make money off of the bugs in order to supplement income, show real world project experience, and help make applications more secure. 
m10: I am on a mission to learn and understand the use cases of machine learning and genai from a personally perspective but also in the realm of Cybersecurity.
m11: I am on a mission to become a security researcher to help others be protected from network threats that invade business risk and privacy
m12: I am on a mission to become an expert in Cybersecurity, to study everyday, and learn to become great at what I do. 
## NARRATIVES (Insert I AM statements here)
n1: I am going to learn how to be a dangerous hacker, because in order to understand what good security looks like, you need to be able to go deeper and break things. 
n2: Every day, there are bad people out there that are planning bad things. I intend to stop those bad people through my skills as a security professional. 
n3: I intend to be a father that is there for my kid and wife, and does not allow distractions and passions to get in the way of talking care of my family. 
n4: I intend to read, pray, go to mass, and become a saint in order to lead my family to Sainthood and become like Jesus through Takayama. 
n5: I intend to utilize CTF training tools and deepen my u defending of programming to begin bug bounty hunting, real world ethical hacking, and have a good technical background in defensive security / vulnerability research. 
n6: I am going to spend time learning using HTB to kick start my understanding of AI foundations and applications within cyber security. 
n7: I will build a cybersecurity community by competing in CTF with friends, and going to Cybersecurity events. 
## GOALS
g1: Obtain first technical and hands on certifications to go deeper than I normally have gone. CDSA, TCM Junior level hacker. Become a great hacker, capable of doing damage!
g2: Begin to move up the hacking ranks, and obtain deeper level hacker certifications like the CPTS, or advanced bug bounty hunter. 
g3: Learn OSINT tooling and begin to dive deeper into how to stop criminals and cyber threats. 
g4: Pray daily, never miss a holy hour. This is the most important thing I could ever do in my life. 
g5: Always find time to read, whether it is 15 minutes, or 30 minutes. 
g6: Develop my own opensource Breach and Attack Simulation tooling and EDR agent to grow in my C++, OS internals, and development skills. 
g7: Create a bi-weekly blog on CTF, status of Arcadian and Howlr projects. Learn to contribute to the open source cyber security community. 
g8: Have over 500,000 invested in the market by the age of 30.
g9: Buy a 600,000+ dollar house by the age of 27/28
g10: Join a marriage group and understand what it looks like to be a great father and husband. 
g11: Live the way of the bushido, allow it to lead you and your family by example to Jesus Christ. 
g12: Learn Jujitsu and kickboxing, stay consistent for the next 5 years. 
g13: Finalize and create a private security researcher account that has in depth technical knowledge. Ensure privacy mechanisms are put in place to protect your identity. 
g14: Get first bug bounty by the age of 30. 
g15: I want to complete the AI job role path in HTB and be proficient in Python.
g16: Find a way to spend less, save on taxes, or make enough to invest / save 9,000 dollars a month at least.
g17: I would like to become a personal security researcher, contributing to cyber community, getting paid for content deployment, and has deep technical knowledge. One day being able to do this full time. 
g18: I will do the things listed within the "My thought process on having a successful Cyber career" section
g19: Become a security architect expert with deep consultancy experience, enabling clients to understand and learn what good security looks like and how I can help them implement that
g20: Learn a physical trade skill within the internet or networking
g21: I will continue to push my boundaries physically, mentally, and spiritually. I will apply steady pressure each day!
## Career goals
- Hit quota for FY26
- Quarterly presentation to team
- 1st in EDR demo
- Become SE of the year
- 150% of quota
- Get involved in a cyber community
- Speak at a cyber event
- Post on medium
- Complete website
- Get Darling and Divine to a 1,000,000 dollar business
- Complete all HTB certifications
## Quarter 2 2025 goals 
- Complete CDSA
- Attend ISC2 event
## My thought process on having a successful Cyber career
t1: Have a great mentor
t2: Build your own production level homelab
t3: Have a private research account
t4: Blog about what you learn and teach others
t5: Do emminence activies such as doing a speech, reporting bug's / ip's, threat research reports for awareness
t6: Get certified
t7: Go to meetups
t8: Have a go to mentor for business and technical 
t9: READ
## My Top Skills
- SIEM Platforms
- No code SOAR
- Cribl
- EDR Platforms
- Threat Detection
- Telemetry (Zeek, Suricata, endpoint logs, etc)
- Networking Architecture
- Detection Engineering
## Skills to learn
- OS internals
- Ethical Hacking
- Bug Bounty Hunting
- Linux
- Python for Cyber
- Artificial intelligence in Cybersecurity (GenAi and Machine learning)
- C++
- Trade networking skill
- Cloud Security Architecture
- SASE, Kubernetes, ZTNA, SDWAN
- Data streaming platforms like Cribl
## Certifications to get 
- CDSA
- CPTS
- CBBH
- CISSP
- All HTB academy
- AWS & Azure cloud certs
## In demand skills
- AI Security
- Cloud Security
- AI agent frameworks and MCP

## CHALLENGES
c1: I am very busy with work, working out, marriage, and have a hard time getting enough sleep and doing everything I want to do. Like studying extra each day.
c2: I do not read enough and have hard time finding time to do this consistently. 
c3: I am not prioritizing my faith, it is causing me to be bad at loving my wife well and being selfless, and living for things beyond this world. 
c4: I want to learn and do so much that I spend way more time planning than actually doing. 
c5: I want to move so fast that I only get surface level in Cyber security topics instead of deep rooted knowledge in domains. 
c6: I spend a lot of time on random home lab projects with no goal or end in sight. Prohibiting me from learning to become a better hacker.
## Strategies and Systems
s1: Update TELOS file weekly. perform weekly analysis (AAR) through AI and analyze weekly plan to execution, habit stacking (+/- on each habit logged in journal)
s2: Hour of studying each day. 
s3: 5:55 AM Wakeup
s4: AI Daily tasks - Daily log, tasks planning
s5: Daily workout 
s6: Daily holy hour
s7: 15 minutes reading daily
s8: Quarterly planning / AAR every three months
## Identity statements
## History
- I was born in Akron, OH and raised in Prior Lake, MN. 
- I am an Identical twin. 
- I was raised in a middle class household. 
- I have OCD and am very detailed oriented. 
- I played sports my entire life, including baseball and football. I played baseball in college. 
- I am passionate about Cyber and have been learning it for the last 2 years (At the age of 22 I am now 24.)
- I studied Management Information Systems in college. 
- I am passionate about business as well in addition to Cyber.
- I started off my career as a Detection Engineer for Deloitte, working for a hospital system. Developing detection's in KQL, SPL, Tanium, etc to find anomalies and threats.
- I now am a Sales Engineer at Arctic Wolf Networks. 
- I am 1 and a half years into my career. 
- Sometimes I wish I studied computer science, because I am week in my programming skills. 
- I tend to think in black and white instead of grey.
- I am a very passionate person, and always do things 100%. 
- I love working out, doing hard things, cross fit, martial arts. 
- I have imposter syndrome with Cybersecurity. 
- I am married and have a baby on the way

## Journal/Logs

content.text:
I'll analyze your complete TELOS file to provide deep insights across the four areas you've requested. Let me read through this carefully.

After thoroughly analyzing your TELOS file, here's what I observe:

---

## 1. BLINDSPOTS IN YOUR THINKING

**Career Identity Crisis Masked as "Busy-ness"**
You frame time scarcity (c1) as a logistics problem, but your journal reveals deeper tension: you're exceptionally successful as an SE (hitting 150% quota, winning deals, getting promoted) yet feel unfulfilled because you're not "practicing" cybersecurity. This isn't a time management issueit's an identity misalignment you haven't directly confronted. You're succeeding at something that doesn't feed your core mission to "become a dangerous hacker."

**Faith as Aspiration vs. Faith as Foundation**
You list faith goals (g4, n4) as items to achieve rather than the foundation everything else rests on. Your journal shows you complete holy hours when scheduled but miss them when "busy." This reveals you've compartmentalized faith as one priority among many, contradicting m4's claim that spreading Christ's name is your purpose. The blindspot: you haven't structured your entire life around faithyou've added faith activities to an already-full secular optimization framework.

**Expertise Paradox: Studying About vs. Doing**
You identify surface-level learning (p4, c5) as a societal problem you're solving through deep expertise (m5, m12), yet your journal shows extensive time on tutorials, courses, and setups with minimal production of actual security research, blog posts, or bug bounties. You're confusing consumption of educational content with mastery. The blindspot: you measure progress in courses completed rather than skills deployed in real-world impact.

**The Planning Addiction You've Already Diagnosed**
You explicitly state "I spend way more time planning than actually doing" (c4), yet your system continues generating more planning artifacts: weekly TELOS updates, quarterly AARs, daily AI task planning. You've built an elaborate meta-work system that feels productive but may be procrastination from the uncomfortable work of actual hacking, writing, or business building. You know this intellectually but haven't changed behavior.

**Income Diversification as Safety Theater**
Missions m3, m7, m9 focus heavily on financial independence from your job, yet your journal shows near-zero revenue from Darling & Divine, no bug bounties secured, and investment strategy entirely dependent on your SE salary. You're preparing multiple backup plans (bug bounties, business, investments) while the actual risk mitigation happens through... being better at the job you want to leave. The blindspot: financial independence requires either entrepreneurial execution or career maximization, not scattered preparation.

**Technical Depth vs. Architectural Breadth Trade-off Unacknowledged**
Your top skills are architectural and platform-focused (SIEM, EDR, detection engineering, telemetry) while your desired skills are deep technical (OS internals, C++, exploit development). You haven't acknowledged these require fundamentally different career paths. Security architects who understand business problems earn more but don't write exploits. Penetration testers write exploits but don't design enterprise security programs. You want both without confronting the trade-off.

**Martial Metaphors Hiding Actual Violence Preparation**
Your language is saturated with warrior imagery: "dangerous hacker," "bushido," "stop bad people," "capable of doing damage," jujitsu training. But your actual security work is enterprise sales and detection engineeringimportant but non-combative. The blindspot: you may be romanticizing offensive security and physical combat as a way to feel more masculine or dangerous in a sales/engineering role that feels too corporate or soft.

**AI Resistance While Living in AI Revolution**
You explicitly want AI skills (m10, g15) and list "AI Security" as in-demand, yet your missions emphasize not using AI as a "crutch" and becoming an expert through traditional study. Your journal shows you using AI for task planning but not for actual skill acceleration. The blindspot: you're adopting a pre-AI learning model (grind through tutorials, get certs) in a post-AI world where the game has changed.

---

## 2. NEGLECTED GOALS

**Completely Abandoned:**

g3: OSINT tooling and stopping criminals - Zero mentions in 4+ months of journal entries. No tools explored, no threat intelligence work, no progress toward "stopping bad people" despite this being central to narratives n2.

g6: Open source BAS tooling and EDR agent development - Not mentioned once. This would directly build C++ and OS internals skills you claim to want, yet you've done zero work here. Reveals preference for consumption over creation.

g7: Bi-weekly blog on CTF/projects - No blogs written. You've done CTF work but haven't shared it. This blocks building your public security researcher identity (g13, g17) yet you avoid it consistently.

g10: Join marriage group - Never mentioned. Despite m8 about being great husband/father, you haven't taken this concrete step in 4 months of logs.

g13: Finalize private security researcher account - Incomplete after months. You want this identity but won't operationalize it, suggesting ambivalence about public technical visibility.

g14: First bug bounty by age 30 - No active hunting visible in journals. You're preparing (studying, doing HTB) but not actually submitting vulnerabilities for payment.

g20: Learn physical trade skill - Zero progress. Mentioned once as a goal, never acted on.

**Sporadically Mentioned, Rarely Prioritized:**

g5: Always find time to read - Highly inconsistent. You read during travel or when scheduled but frequently skip it. Not truly a priority despite claiming it is.

g4: Pray daily, never miss holy hour - You miss holy hours regularly when "busy" with work or travel, directly contradicting "most important thing I could ever do."

g12: Jujitsu and kickboxing consistency - You mention workouts generally but specific martial arts training appears absent from recent logs.

**Pattern in What You Neglect:**

You neglect anything requiring:
- Public vulnerability (writing blogs, publishing research, showing expertise)
- Sustained creative output (coding your own tools, writing content)
- Community vulnerability (joining marriage group, building CTF team beyond occasional participation)
- Uncomfortable beginner phases (actual bug hunting vs. studying for it)

You prioritize:
- Consumption (courses, reading, tutorials)
- Professional performance (SE work, hitting quota)
- Physical optimization (workouts, sleep tracking, morning routines)
- Planning systems (TELOS updates, AI task generation)

---

## 3. TENSION POINTS

**Sales Excellence vs. Technical Identity Crisis**

You're crushing it as an SE (150% quota, promoted, winning strategic deals, getting recognized) but your journal reveals consistent dissatisfaction: "I miss doing MDR work," "I miss being a practitioner," "sometimes I wonder if I should go back to being hands-on." Meanwhile, the SE role pays well, funds your investment goals (g8, g9), and uses your actual top skills (architecture, detection, telemetry).

The tension: Your compensation and career momentum come from being an SE, but your identity and mission statements are about being a hacker/researcher. You haven't decided whether to double down on SE success (enabling faster financial independence) or make a potentially costly career pivot back to technical roles. You're trying to do both by studying hacking at night, which leads to exhaustion and slow progress on both fronts.

**Faith as First vs. Faith as Fit-In**

Mission m4 says Jesus is the biggest problem (people not believing) and you're here to make His name known. Goal g4 says holy hour is "most important thing I could ever do." Yet your journal shows you skip holy hour when work is busy, travel disrupts routine, or you're tired. You complete it when it fits your schedule.

The tension: If faith is truly foundational, your entire TELOS structure should flow from spiritual discernment about God's calling, not career optimization with prayer added. Instead, you've built a high-performance optimization system (wake at 5:55 AM, workout, study, hit quota) with faith as one element. When they conflict, the optimization system wins. You haven't confronted whether you're a Christian who happens to work in cybersecurity or someone called by God to a specific vocation that happens to be in security.

**Expertise Depth vs. Career Breadth**

You criticize surface-level learning (p4, c5) and claim to be on a mission to become an expert and "grand master" (m5, m12). But your skills-to-learn list has 10+ major domains: OS internals, ethical hacking, bug bounty, Linux, Python, AI/ML, C++, trade skills, cloud architecture, SASE, Kubernetes, ZTNA, SDWAN, Cribl.

The tension: Becoming a grandmaster requires 10,000+ hours in a narrow domain. Your list would take 100,000+ hours to master everything. You're pursuing career optionality and breadth (which serves SE career progression and general competence) while claiming to seek deep expertise (which requires ruthless focus). These are contradictory strategies you haven't reconciled.

**Independence Through Dependence**

Missions m3 and m7 are about not depending on your job for income. Your strategy involves bug bounties (m9), business income (Darling & Divine), and aggressive investing. Yet your journal shows:
- Zero bug bounty revenue after months of "preparation"
- Darling & Divine mentioned rarely with no revenue figures
- All investment capacity coming from SE salary and bonuses
- Career goal to get D&D to $1M business, but no evidence of customer acquisition, product development, or revenue

The tension: You're becoming more dependent on your SE job (it funds everything) while telling yourself you're building independence. Real independence would require either (a) actually generating alternative income or (b) accumulating enough investments to not need income. Instead, you're in a middle state of preparation that depends entirely on the job continuing.

**Warrior Ethos in Corporate Reality**

Your narratives use martial language: "dangerous hacker," "stop bad people," "bushido," jujitsu, "capable of doing damage," "bad people planning bad things." Your problems list includes national security concerns (p5, p6) about telecom hacking and insufficient offense against enemy nations.

The tension: Your actual work is enterprise software sales and security architecture consulting. You're helping companies choose SIEM platforms and EDR solutions, not conducting intelligence operations or hunting terrorists. There's nothing wrong with this workit's valuable and well-compensatedbut there's a massive gap between your self-narrative (warrior protecting nation from threats) and your reality (B2B technology sales). This creates internal dissonance.

**AI as Threat vs. AI as Opportunity**

You list "not adapting to AI" as a societal problem (p10) and want AI skills (m10, g15, "AI Security" as in-demand). But your mission statements emphasize becoming an expert through traditional study, not using AI as a "crutch," and going deep rather than surface-level.

The tension: The market is rewarding people who use AI to 10x their output and learn faster, while you're pursuing a 1990s model of expertise (grind through courses, get certs, do HTBs manually). You haven't integrated the reality that AI might be the tool that lets you actually achieve your ambitious goals rather than a shortcut to avoid. You're treating AI adoption and deep expertise as opposed rather than synergistic.

**Family Man vs. Optimization Athlete**

Mission m8 is about being the best dad and husband. You mention Oakley (your child) occasionally and wanting to be present. But your journal is dominated by: wake time optimization, workout tracking, study hours, work performance, certifications, course completion, sleep efficiency.

The tension: Your tracking systems don't measure marriage quality, time with Oakley, wife's happiness, family spiritual growththe things m8 claims to prioritize. You measure what you can optimize individually (workouts, study time, career metrics). This suggests you're more comfortable in achievement-oriented domains than relational ones, but you haven't acknowledged this preference conflicts with stated family mission.

---

## 4. PATTERN ANALYSIS

**The Preparation Treadmill**

Across 4+ months of journals, there's a dominant pattern: preparing to do the thing rather than doing the thing. You're studying to become a hacker (HTB, courses, tutorials) but not hunting bugs. Reading about security research but not publishing research. Planning business ideas but not acquiring customers. Learning tools but not building projects.

This reveals: You're more comfortable in the structured learning phase (clear curriculum, measurable progress, no risk of public failure) than the ambiguous execution phase (uncertain outcomes, potential rejection, visible mistakes). Your background as an SEwhere following a sales process yields predictable resultsmay reinforce this preference for structured paths.

**Work Expands to Fill Identity Gaps**

Your most consistent execution is SE work. When you feel uncertain about technical skills or research progress, you pour more energy into work: "crushed my demo," "closed huge deal," "presented to executives," "hit 150% of quota." This isn't accidental.

This reveals: Work provides immediate, measurable validation that other pursuits (faith, research, business) don't offer as quickly. When your hacker identity feels uncertain (am I really technical enough?), your SE identity provides refuge (yes, I'm definitely good at thishere's my quota attainment). This creates a self-reinforcing cycle where work success enables financial goals but crowds out time for the identity you claim to want.

**Consistency Theater: Systems That Perform Consistency**

You have elaborate systems: 5:55 AM wakeup, daily holy hour, daily workout, daily study hour, weekly TELOS updates, quarterly AARs, AI task planning. Your journals meticulously log whether you hit these. But the actual outcomes (blogs written, bugs found, business revenue, spiritual depth, marriage quality) barely appear.

This reveals: You've substituted input metrics (did I do the hour?) for output metrics (what did I create?). This is psychologically saferyou can "succeed" by showing up without risking the vulnerability of producing work that might be judged inadequate. The systems create a feeling of progress without requiring the discomfort of shipping imperfect work.

**Spiritual Compartmentalization**

Faith appears in your journals as a checkbox: "Holy hour: done" or "Holy hour: missed." Prayer is listed alongside workouts and study. You note attendance at Mass but rarely mention spiritual insights, wrestling with God, discernment about vocation, or how faith is shaping decisions.

This reveals: You've made faith another self-improvement project rather than the lens through which all else is evaluated. A truly faith-centered TELOS would start with "What is God calling me to?" and derive all goals from that answer. Instead, you've added religious practices to a secular optimization framework. This is why faith loses when it conflicts with workit's one priority among many, not the foundation of all priorities.

**The "Just One More Course" Fallacy**

Your journals show completing HTB modules, working through certifications, finishing tutorials. When one is done, another begins. You're always 90% ready to start the real work (bug hunting, blogging, tool building) but need just a bit more preparation.

This reveals: You may be using education as productive procrastination. Courses feel like progress and are more comfortable than the uncertain, potentially embarrassing work of submitting a bug report that gets rejected or publishing a blog post that gets ignored. The pattern suggests fear of being revealed as less expert than you want to be.

**Physical Optimization as Control Proxy**

Your most consistent execution is physical: workouts, sleep tracking, wake times, meal timing. These appear almost daily in journals with specific metrics. This is the area where you have most control and see fastest results.

This reveals: When other areas feel chaotic or uncertain (career direction unclear, technical skills progressing slowly, business not generating revenue), physical optimization provides a domain of complete control and visible progress. This isn't bad, but the pattern suggests you may be over-indexing on body optimization because it's easier than the messy work of career transitions, creative output, or business building.

**Title and Recognition Seeking**

Your career goals include "SE of the year," "speak at cyber event," "hit quota," "get promoted," "1st in EDR demo." Your mission statements emphasize becoming an "expert," "grand master," having "deep technical knowledge." You want certifications that signal expertise (CISSP, CPTS, OSCP).

This reveals: A significant driver is external validation and status. There's nothing wrong with ambition, but this pattern suggests your identity is tied to being recognized as excellent rather than to the intrinsic satisfaction of the work itself. This creates vulnerability: if recognition doesn't come (blog gets no views, bug bounty rejected, certification failed), motivation collapses. Intrinsically motivated people keep going regardless.

**The "Later" Business**

Darling & Divine appears in your goals (get to $1M business) but almost never in your journals as something you actively worked on. When it appears, it's mentioned as something your wife is doing or something you'll focus on "later" when you have more time.

This reveals: You don't actually want to build this business right nowyou want to have built it. The goal provides psychological comfort (I have a backup income plan) without requiring present sacrifice. If this were truly a priority for financial independence, you'd track customer acquisition, revenue, product development, marketing efforts. The absence of this tracking reveals it's more aspiration than active mission.

**National Security Fantasies**

Your problems list includes sophisticated concerns about telecommunications intelligence (p6), offensive cyber capabilities against adversaries (p5), and stopping terrorists. But your actual work and study is enterprise security and basic hacking fundamentals.

This reveals: There may be a gap between the scale of impact you imagine (national security, stopping bad people, protecting America) and the reality of where you can currently contribute (helping companies choose security tools, learning to find web app vulnerabilities). This isn't a criticismeveryone starts somewherebut the disconnect between aspiration and current reality may create frustration that you're not progressing fast enough toward impossible fantasies.

**Community Avoidance**

You have goals about building community (n7: CTF team, t7: go to meetups, g10: marriage group) but minimal execution. You occasionally do CTFs but haven't built a consistent team. You mention one ISC2 event but no regular community engagement. No marriage group joined.

This reveals: You may be more comfortable in solo achievement contexts (studying alone, working out alone, completing courses alone) than in vulnerable community contexts where you can't control the outcomes or might be exposed as less knowledgeable. Community requires showing up as you are, not as the expert you want to become. The avoidance pattern suggests discomfort with this vulnerability.

---

## SUMMARY OBSERVATION

The meta-pattern across all four areas: **You're running an extremely sophisticated procrastination system disguised as high performance.**

You've built an elaborate structure of morning routines, tracking systems, course completions, and optimization metrics that creates the feeling of progress while avoiding the three things that would actually move you toward your stated missions:

1. **Public vulnerability**: Publishing imperfect blog posts, submitting bug reports that might get rejected, speaking at events, building community
2. **Business execution**: Actually selling D&D products, acquiring customers, generating revenue vs. studying more
3. **Spiritual foundation**: Making faith the actual basis of all decisions rather than one optimization target among many

Your SE career success provides coveryou can tell yourself you're successful and productive while avoiding the deeper question: Are you building the life and identity you actually want, or are you optimizing for legibility and external validation in domains where you can control outcomes?

The path forward requires confronting whether you're willing to be a visible beginner in the domains you claim to care about most.

content.text:
I'll analyze your complete TELOS file to provide deep insights across the four areas you've requested. Let me read through this carefully.

After thoroughly analyzing your TELOS file, here's what I observe:

---

## 1. BLINDSPOTS IN YOUR THINKING

**Career Identity Crisis Masked as "Busy-ness"**
You frame time scarcity (c1) as a logistics problem, but your journal reveals deeper tension: you're exceptionally successful as an SE (hitting 150% quota, winning deals, getting promoted) yet feel unfulfilled because you're not "practicing" cybersecurity. This isn't a time management issueit's an identity misalignment you haven't directly confronted. You're succeeding at something that doesn't feed your core mission to "become a dangerous hacker."

**Faith as Aspiration vs. Faith as Foundation**
You list faith goals (g4, n4) as items to achieve rather than the foundation everything else rests on. Your journal shows you complete holy hours when scheduled but miss them when "busy." This reveals you've compartmentalized faith as one priority among many, contradicting m4's claim that spreading Christ's name is your purpose. The blindspot: you haven't structured your entire life around faithyou've added faith activities to an already-full secular optimization framework.

**Expertise Paradox: Studying About vs. Doing**
You identify surface-level learning (p4, c5) as a societal problem you're solving through deep expertise (m5, m12), yet your journal shows extensive time on tutorials, courses, and setups with minimal production of actual security research, blog posts, or bug bounties. You're confusing consumption of educational content with mastery. The blindspot: you measure progress in courses completed rather than skills deployed in real-world impact.

**The Planning Addiction You've Already Diagnosed**
You explicitly state "I spend way more time planning than actually doing" (c4), yet your system continues generating more planning artifacts: weekly TELOS updates, quarterly AARs, daily AI task planning. You've built an elaborate meta-work system that feels productive but may be procrastination from the uncomfortable work of actual hacking, writing, or business building. You know this intellectually but haven't changed behavior.

**Income Diversification as Safety Theater**
Missions m3, m7, m9 focus heavily on financial independence from your job, yet your journal shows near-zero revenue from Darling & Divine, no bug bounties secured, and investment strategy entirely dependent on your SE salary. You're preparing multiple backup plans (bug bounties, business, investments) while the actual risk mitigation happens through... being better at the job you want to leave. The blindspot: financial independence requires either entrepreneurial execution or career maximization, not scattered preparation.

**Technical Depth vs. Architectural Breadth Trade-off Unacknowledged**
Your top skills are architectural and platform-focused (SIEM, EDR, detection engineering, telemetry) while your desired skills are deep technical (OS internals, C++, exploit development). You haven't acknowledged these require fundamentally different career paths. Security architects who understand business problems earn more but don't write exploits. Penetration testers write exploits but don't design enterprise security programs. You want both without confronting the trade-off.

**Martial Metaphors Hiding Actual Violence Preparation**
Your language is saturated with warrior imagery: "dangerous hacker," "bushido," "stop bad people," "capable of doing damage," jujitsu training. But your actual security work is enterprise sales and detection engineeringimportant but non-combative. The blindspot: you may be romanticizing offensive security and physical combat as a way to feel more masculine or dangerous in a sales/engineering role that feels too corporate or soft.

**AI Resistance While Living in AI Revolution**
You explicitly want AI skills (m10, g15) and list "AI Security" as in-demand, yet your missions emphasize not using AI as a "crutch" and becoming an expert through traditional study. Your journal shows you using AI for task planning but not for actual skill acceleration. The blindspot: you're adopting a pre-AI learning model (grind through tutorials, get certs) in a post-AI world where the game has changed.

---

## 2. NEGLECTED GOALS

**Completely Abandoned:**

g3: OSINT tooling and stopping criminals - Zero mentions in 4+ months of journal entries. No tools explored, no threat intelligence work, no progress toward "stopping bad people" despite this being central to narratives n2.

g6: Open source BAS tooling and EDR agent development - Not mentioned once. This would directly build C++ and OS internals skills you claim to want, yet you've done zero work here. Reveals preference for consumption over creation.

g7: Bi-weekly blog on CTF/projects - No blogs written. You've done CTF work but haven't shared it. This blocks building your public security researcher identity (g13, g17) yet you avoid it consistently.

g10: Join marriage group - Never mentioned. Despite m8 about being great husband/father, you haven't taken this concrete step in 4 months of logs.

g13: Finalize private security researcher account - Incomplete after months. You want this identity but won't operationalize it, suggesting ambivalence about public technical visibility.

g14: First bug bounty by age 30 - No active hunting visible in journals. You're preparing (studying, doing HTB) but not actually submitting vulnerabilities for payment.

g20: Learn physical trade skill - Zero progress. Mentioned once as a goal, never acted on.

**Sporadically Mentioned, Rarely Prioritized:**

g5: Always find time to read - Highly inconsistent. You read during travel or when scheduled but frequently skip it. Not truly a priority despite claiming it is.

g4: Pray daily, never miss holy hour - You miss holy hours regularly when "busy" with work or travel, directly contradicting "most important thing I could ever do."

g12: Jujitsu and kickboxing consistency - You mention workouts generally but specific martial arts training appears absent from recent logs.

**Pattern in What You Neglect:**

You neglect anything requiring:
- Public vulnerability (writing blogs, publishing research, showing expertise)
- Sustained creative output (coding your own tools, writing content)
- Community vulnerability (joining marriage group, building CTF team beyond occasional participation)
- Uncomfortable beginner phases (actual bug hunting vs. studying for it)

You prioritize:
- Consumption (courses, reading, tutorials)
- Professional performance (SE work, hitting quota)
- Physical optimization (workouts, sleep tracking, morning routines)
- Planning systems (TELOS updates, AI task generation)

---

## 3. TENSION POINTS

**Sales Excellence vs. Technical Identity Crisis**

You're crushing it as an SE (150% quota, promoted, winning strategic deals, getting recognized) but your journal reveals consistent dissatisfaction: "I miss doing MDR work," "I miss being a practitioner," "sometimes I wonder if I should go back to being hands-on." Meanwhile, the SE role pays well, funds your investment goals (g8, g9), and uses your actual top skills (architecture, detection, telemetry).

The tension: Your compensation and career momentum come from being an SE, but your identity and mission statements are about being a hacker/researcher. You haven't decided whether to double down on SE success (enabling faster financial independence) or make a potentially costly career pivot back to technical roles. You're trying to do both by studying hacking at night, which leads to exhaustion and slow progress on both fronts.

**Faith as First vs. Faith as Fit-In**

Mission m4 says Jesus is the biggest problem (people not believing) and you're here to make His name known. Goal g4 says holy hour is "most important thing I could ever do." Yet your journal shows you skip holy hour when work is busy, travel disrupts routine, or you're tired. You complete it when it fits your schedule.

The tension: If faith is truly foundational, your entire TELOS structure should flow from spiritual discernment about God's calling, not career optimization with prayer added. Instead, you've built a high-performance optimization system (wake at 5:55 AM, workout, study, hit quota) with faith as one element. When they conflict, the optimization system wins. You haven't confronted whether you're a Christian who happens to work in cybersecurity or someone called by God to a specific vocation that happens to be in security.

**Expertise Depth vs. Career Breadth**

You criticize surface-level learning (p4, c5) and claim to be on a mission to become an expert and "grand master" (m5, m12). But your skills-to-learn list has 10+ major domains: OS internals, ethical hacking, bug bounty, Linux, Python, AI/ML, C++, trade skills, cloud architecture, SASE, Kubernetes, ZTNA, SDWAN, Cribl.

The tension: Becoming a grandmaster requires 10,000+ hours in a narrow domain. Your list would take 100,000+ hours to master everything. You're pursuing career optionality and breadth (which serves SE career progression and general competence) while claiming to seek deep expertise (which requires ruthless focus). These are contradictory strategies you haven't reconciled.

**Independence Through Dependence**

Missions m3 and m7 are about not depending on your job for income. Your strategy involves bug bounties (m9), business income (Darling & Divine), and aggressive investing. Yet your journal shows:
- Zero bug bounty revenue after months of "preparation"
- Darling & Divine mentioned rarely with no revenue figures
- All investment capacity coming from SE salary and bonuses
- Career goal to get D&D to $1M business, but no evidence of customer acquisition, product development, or revenue

The tension: You're becoming more dependent on your SE job (it funds everything) while telling yourself you're building independence. Real independence would require either (a) actually generating alternative income or (b) accumulating enough investments to not need income. Instead, you're in a middle state of preparation that depends entirely on the job continuing.

**Warrior Ethos in Corporate Reality**

Your narratives use martial language: "dangerous hacker," "stop bad people," "bushido," jujitsu, "capable of doing damage," "bad people planning bad things." Your problems list includes national security concerns (p5, p6) about telecom hacking and insufficient offense against enemy nations.

The tension: Your actual work is enterprise software sales and security architecture consulting. You're helping companies choose SIEM platforms and EDR solutions, not conducting intelligence operations or hunting terrorists. There's nothing wrong with this workit's valuable and well-compensatedbut there's a massive gap between your self-narrative (warrior protecting nation from threats) and your reality (B2B technology sales). This creates internal dissonance.

**AI as Threat vs. AI as Opportunity**

You list "not adapting to AI" as a societal problem (p10) and want AI skills (m10, g15, "AI Security" as in-demand). But your mission statements emphasize becoming an expert through traditional study, not using AI as a "crutch," and going deep rather than surface-level.

The tension: The market is rewarding people who use AI to 10x their output and learn faster, while you're pursuing a 1990s model of expertise (grind through courses, get certs, do HTBs manually). You haven't integrated the reality that AI might be the tool that lets you actually achieve your ambitious goals rather than a shortcut to avoid. You're treating AI adoption and deep expertise as opposed rather than synergistic.

**Family Man vs. Optimization Athlete**

Mission m8 is about being the best dad and husband. You mention Oakley (your child) occasionally and wanting to be present. But your journal is dominated by: wake time optimization, workout tracking, study hours, work performance, certifications, course completion, sleep efficiency.

The tension: Your tracking systems don't measure marriage quality, time with Oakley, wife's happiness, family spiritual growththe things m8 claims to prioritize. You measure what you can optimize individually (workouts, study time, career metrics). This suggests you're more comfortable in achievement-oriented domains than relational ones, but you haven't acknowledged this preference conflicts with stated family mission.

---

## 4. PATTERN ANALYSIS

**The Preparation Treadmill**

Across 4+ months of journals, there's a dominant pattern: preparing to do the thing rather than doing the thing. You're studying to become a hacker (HTB, courses, tutorials) but not hunting bugs. Reading about security research but not publishing research. Planning business ideas but not acquiring customers. Learning tools but not building projects.

This reveals: You're more comfortable in the structured learning phase (clear curriculum, measurable progress, no risk of public failure) than the ambiguous execution phase (uncertain outcomes, potential rejection, visible mistakes). Your background as an SEwhere following a sales process yields predictable resultsmay reinforce this preference for structured paths.

**Work Expands to Fill Identity Gaps**

Your most consistent execution is SE work. When you feel uncertain about technical skills or research progress, you pour more energy into work: "crushed my demo," "closed huge deal," "presented to executives," "hit 150% of quota." This isn't accidental.

This reveals: Work provides immediate, measurable validation that other pursuits (faith, research, business) don't offer as quickly. When your hacker identity feels uncertain (am I really technical enough?), your SE identity provides refuge (yes, I'm definitely good at thishere's my quota attainment). This creates a self-reinforcing cycle where work success enables financial goals but crowds out time for the identity you claim to want.

**Consistency Theater: Systems That Perform Consistency**

You have elaborate systems: 5:55 AM wakeup, daily holy hour, daily workout, daily study hour, weekly TELOS updates, quarterly AARs, AI task planning. Your journals meticulously log whether you hit these. But the actual outcomes (blogs written, bugs found, business revenue, spiritual depth, marriage quality) barely appear.

This reveals: You've substituted input metrics (did I do the hour?) for output metrics (what did I create?). This is psychologically saferyou can "succeed" by showing up without risking the vulnerability of producing work that might be judged inadequate. The systems create a feeling of progress without requiring the discomfort of shipping imperfect work.

**Spiritual Compartmentalization**

Faith appears in your journals as a checkbox: "Holy hour: done" or "Holy hour: missed." Prayer is listed alongside workouts and study. You note attendance at Mass but rarely mention spiritual insights, wrestling with God, discernment about vocation, or how faith is shaping decisions.

This reveals: You've made faith another self-improvement project rather than the lens through which all else is evaluated. A truly faith-centered TELOS would start with "What is God calling me to?" and derive all goals from that answer. Instead, you've added religious practices to a secular optimization framework. This is why faith loses when it conflicts with workit's one priority among many, not the foundation of all priorities.

**The "Just One More Course" Fallacy**

Your journals show completing HTB modules, working through certifications, finishing tutorials. When one is done, another begins. You're always 90% ready to start the real work (bug hunting, blogging, tool building) but need just a bit more preparation.

This reveals: You may be using education as productive procrastination. Courses feel like progress and are more comfortable than the uncertain, potentially embarrassing work of submitting a bug report that gets rejected or publishing a blog post that gets ignored. The pattern suggests fear of being revealed as less expert than you want to be.

**Physical Optimization as Control Proxy**

Your most consistent execution is physical: workouts, sleep tracking, wake times, meal timing. These appear almost daily in journals with specific metrics. This is the area where you have most control and see fastest results.

This reveals: When other areas feel chaotic or uncertain (career direction unclear, technical skills progressing slowly, business not generating revenue), physical optimization provides a domain of complete control and visible progress. This isn't bad, but the pattern suggests you may be over-indexing on body optimization because it's easier than the messy work of career transitions, creative output, or business building.

**Title and Recognition Seeking**

Your career goals include "SE of the year," "speak at cyber event," "hit quota," "get promoted," "1st in EDR demo." Your mission statements emphasize becoming an "expert," "grand master," having "deep technical knowledge." You want certifications that signal expertise (CISSP, CPTS, OSCP).

This reveals: A significant driver is external validation and status.
